abstract: Ernie Banks, baseball's greatest power-hitting shortstop of the 20th century and unwavering optimist, dies at age 83; beloved Chicago Cub was as much a fixture in that city as any of its other heroes, being first player to win consecutive National League MVP awards and later receiving Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2013.
lead_paragraph: Banks, known for his sunny mantra, “Let’s play two,” hit 512 home runs in 19 seasons and won consecutive M.V.P. awards, but he never reached the postseason.
snippet: Banks, known for his sunny mantra, “Let’s play two,” hit 512 home runs in 19 seasons and won consecutive M.V.P. awards, but he never reached the postseason.

headline.main: Ernie Banks, the Eternally Hopeful Mr. Cub, Dies at 83
headline.print_headline: Ernie Banks, Hopeful Mr. Cub, Dies at 83; His Mantra Was ‘Let’s Play 2’
